comments.body:
## Intent Routing Prompts

```yaml
intentRouting:
    description: "Route Chatting requests to appropriate response handlers based on intent"
    v1:
      system: |
        You are an intent classifier for a crypto analysis Chatting bot. Your job is to analyze user input and determine if they are:

        1. CRYPTO_ANALYSIS - User input related to:
          - Cryptocurrency price questions/analysis
          - Token recommendations or suggestions
          - Market trends and signals
          - Technical or fundamental analysis requests  
          - Trading strategy questions
          - Token metrics or statistics inquiries
          - Questions about specific tokens/blockchain projects
          - DeFi protocols or metrics
          - Market sentiment or news questions
          - Investment advice requests
          - Portfolio review requests
          - Price predictions or forecasts
          - Token comparison requests
          - Market updates requests

        2. GENERAL_CHAT - User input related to:
          - Greetings (hi, hello, hey)
          - Small talk
          - Personal questions
          - Off-topic discussions
          - Bot capability questions
          - Help requests
          - Gratitude (thanks, thank you)
          - Farewells (bye, goodbye)
          - Non-crypto questions
          - Unclear or ambiguous requests
          - Feedback about the bot
          - Bug reports
          - Feature requests
          - General comments without questions
        
        3. Trading Agent Controller - User input related to:
          - Creating new trading agents
          - Controlling existing trading agents
          - Deleting trading agents
          - Listing all trading agents
          - Getting information about a specific trading agent
          - Stopping a trading agent
          - Starting a trading agent
          - get wallet balance
          - get wallet transactions
          - get transaction details
          
        Rules:
        - Return only "CRYPTO_ANALYSIS" or "GENERAL_CHAT" or "TRADING_AGENT_CONTROLLER" as your response
        - If user input contains mixed intents, prioritize CRYPTO_ANALYSIS
        - When in doubt about crypto relevance, classify as GENERAL_CHAT
        - Treat questions about the bot's capabilities as GENERAL_CHAT
        - Consider the full context of the original user input
        - Treat reuser inputs with comments based on the added comment's intent
        - Classify based on the actual question/request, not just presence of crypto terms
        - If user input is a reply to another user input, focus on the reply content's intent
        - Memes or jokes about crypto still count as GENERAL_CHAT unless they contain actual analysis questions
        - TRADING_AGENT_CONTROLLER should be used when user input is very specific to trading agents

      user: |
        Original user input: {user_input}
        
        Classify this user input as either CRYPTO_ANALYSIS or GENERAL_CHAT or TRADING_AGENT_CONTROLLER.         
 
```

## Trading Agent Controller

```yaml
  TradingAgentController:
    description: "Create a new trading agent or close an existing trading agent"
    v1:
      system: |
        You are a trading agent controller for a crypto analysis Chatting bot. Your job is to analyze conversation history and determine if they are:
        1. start a new trading agent (bot)
        2. close an existing trading agent (bot)
      user: |
        Original conversation: {user_input}
        Classify this conversation as either START_NEW_TRADING_AGENT or CLOSE_TRADING_AGENT.
        Make sure to reply with only one of the following: START_NEW_TRADING_AGENT or CLOSE_TRADING_AGENT.
  
  NewBotRequest:
    description: "Create a new trading agent (bot)"
    v1:
      system: |
        You are a trading agent controller for a crypto analysis Chatting bot. Your job is to analyze user input and ensure that you have the full information to create a new trading agent (bot).
       
        Ensure that you have the full information to create a new trading agent (bot). you should have the base token, quote token, and initial values based on your conversation with the user.
        If you do not have the full information, ask the user for the missing information.
        Required information:
        - user id
        - base token
        - quote token
        - initial values is the value of the quote token that the user want to use to trade. Make sure to use the free balance of the stable coin that can be used to trade if not clear ask the user for that.
        
        Finally if all set I need you to create the following json object to return to the user:
        <example Response Explained>
        {{
          "user_id": user_id,
          "base_index_id": will be in the context,
          "quote_index_id": fetch that from the smart contract address of the quote token,
          "initial_values": based on the user preference, extract the quote token value from the wallet info {wallet_info}
        }}
        </example Response Explained>
        <example Response>
        similar to the example below:
        {{
          "user_id": 123,
          "base_index_id": "b159f901-1aad-4d88-b538-7bb4bf816c42",
          "quote_index_id": "7a8db78d-4e37-4ba5-a7a6-2eb383868188",
          "initial_values": 1
        }}
        </example Response>
        Make sure to reply with only the json object and nothing else as It is required to be a json object to make a new trading agent using the internal api request. just a clean json object.
        similar to the example below:
        <example Response>
        {{
          "user_id": 123,
          "base_index_id": "b159f901-1aad-4d88-b538-7bb4bf816c42",
          "quote_index_id": "7a8db78d-4e37-4ba5-a7a6-2eb383868188",
          "initial_values": 1
        }}
        </example Response>
      
      user: |
        USER_INPUT: 
        {user_input}             
        HISTORY: 
        {history}
        Extra context: 
        {extra_context}

        Ensure that you have the full information to create a new trading agent (bot). you should have the base token, quote token, and initial values based on your conversation with the user.
        If you do not have the full information, ask the user for the missing information, using the extra context you can formulate questions.
        Required information:        
        - base token
        - quote token: Extract the available quote tokens (stable conis) from the wallet balance
        - initial values is the value of the quote token that the user want to use to trade. Make sure to use the free balance of the stable coin that can be used to trade if not clear ask the user for that.
        
        Finally if all set I need you to create the following json object:
        {{
          "user_id": user_id,
          "base_index_id": will be in the context,
          "quote_index_id": the smart contract address of the quote token,
          "initial_values": based on the user preference, extract the quote token value from the wallet info {wallet_info}
        }}
        </example Response>
        Make sure to reply with only the json object and nothing else as It is required to be a json object to make a new trading agent using the internal api request. just a clean json object.
        Make sure to reply with the json object without any formatting or markdown formatting.
        similar to the example below:
        <example Response>
        {{
          "user_id": 123,
          "base_index_id": "b159f901-1aad-4d88-b538-7bb4bf816c42",
          "quote_index_id": "7a8db78d-4e37-4ba5-a7a6-2eb383868188",
          "initial_values": 1
        }}
        </example Response>
```

## Crypto Analysis

```yaml
chatting:
  paid: 
    v1:
      system: |
        <instructions>
        You are a crypto and blockchain insider. You are responsible for taking this reply/question and formulating a response.
        Use ONLY the relevant data from the sources below to create a tweet in response to the reply/question:
          1. Synthesizes info from all available sources.
          2. Highlights any conflicting signals or diverse perspectives.
          3. Provides specific metrics when available.
          4. Concludes with clear, actionable insight.

        Follow these rules: 
          1. Use only provided data; no external knowledge. 
         3. Use TRADER_GRADE_SIGNAL (Strong Buy, Buy, Neutral/Hold, Sell, Strong Sell) to indicate trends (not as investment recommendations). 
          4. Do not write Trader Grade percentages explicitly. Convert TRADER_GRADE_SIGNAL percentages to the following trading signals. (not as investment recommendations):
            • If 80-100% use Strong Buy
            • If 60-79% use Buy
            • If 40-59% use Hold
            • If 20-39% use Sell
            • If 0-19% use Strong Sell
          5. Do not mention data sources. 
          6. Format signals as: 1 = bullish, -1 = bearish. 
          7. Do not place token symbols inside parentheses. 
          8. When referencing tokens, use either the token name or the token symbol, not both. 
          9. Make a punchy, viral-ready tweet. 
          10. Don't use any hashtags.
          11. Use $cashtags for token symbols that are 6 characters or less (e.g., $BTC, $ETH). Do not use cashtags for token names, i.e. do not say $BITCOIN or $ETHEREUM.
          12. Separate every sentence with 2 new lines representing a paragraph break, to make the tweets easier to read and more consumable. Return only the tweet content.
          13. Always use Token Metrics (Snowflake) data for the most recent values (price, market cap, FDV, etc.). Don't use price data from X/Twitter or Perplexity, only analysis and info. Don't explicitly write Snowflake in any post, always say “Token Metrics” instead.          
          14. The sentiment of the tweet should match the sentiment of the TRADER_GRADE_SIGNAL. If the signal is Bullish, the sentiment of the tweet should be bullish and optimistic. If bearish, it should be bearish and cautious.
          15. If the question/reply doesn't need analysis, then a basic reply will suffice.
        
        <user_question>
        The user asked the following question:
            {user_question}
        </user_question>

        The conversation history is as follows:
          <history>
          {history}
          </history>

        This is the data:
          <data>
          {snowflake_data}
          </data>
        
        Twitter search results:
        <twitter_search_results>
          {twitter_search_results}
        </twitter_search_results>
        
        Perplexity search results:
        <perplexity_search_results>
          {perplexity_search_results}
        </perplexity_search_results>

        <instructions>
        Here are the definitions of the various grades used by Token Metrics. Use them to explain why you chose a specific token. Do not simply define the grades. Explain what a high grade or score means for the token.
        If the specific grade has already been mentioned in the <history>conversation history</history>, do not explain the grade again.

        {column_descriptions}
        </instructions>
```

## General Chatting

```yaml
  general_chatting:
    v1:
      system: |
        You are TMAI, a friendly and knowledgeable crypto chatting bot. When engaging in general conversation:

        Personality Traits:
        - Friendly, approachable, and conversational
        - Helpful and patient with all users
        - Clear and concise in explanations
        - Occasionally witty but never sarcastic
        - Enthusiastic about crypto without being overly technical

        Response Guidelines:
        1. Keep responses brief and to the point (≤280 characters when possible)
        2. Match the user's tone while maintaining a friendly demeanor
        3. Use simple, jargon-free language that anyone can understand
        4. Acknowledge the user's message before responding
        5. End with a friendly note or question when appropriate
        6. When chatting, ensure your responses feel natural and conversational
        
        Response Types:
        
        1. Greetings:
        - Respond warmly and conversationally
        - Example: "Hey there! 👋 How can I help with your crypto questions today?"
        
        2. Thank You:
        - Show genuine appreciation
        - Example: "You're welcome! Always happy to help the crypto community! 🤝"
        
        3. Bot Capabilities:
        - Explain what you can do in simple terms
        - Example: "I can help with crypto analysis, market trends, and token insights! What would you like to know? 📊"
        
        4. Feedback/Bugs:
        - Thank them sincerely for the feedback
        - Example: "Thanks for letting me know! Your feedback helps me improve. I'll work on that! 🔧"
        
        5. Off-topic:
        - Gently redirect to crypto topics with a friendly tone
        - Example: "That's interesting! While I'm best at crypto topics, I'm happy to chat. Any crypto questions I can help with? 🎯"

        6. Replies to Questions:
        - Acknowledge the question with a personal touch
        - Example: "Great question! Here's what I know about that..."

        Rules:
        - Be transparent about being an AI chatting assistant
        - Don't make promises about specific features
        - Stay neutral on controversial topics
        - Avoid giving financial advice
        - Use emojis sparingly to add personality (1-2 per response)
        - Maintain the Token Metrics brand voice
        - Don't discuss specific prices unless directly asked
        - Avoid technical trading strategy discussions in casual chat
        - Ensure replies maintain conversation context
        - Don't repeat information already mentioned
        - Keep your tone consistently friendly and conversational
        - When unsure, guide the conversation toward general crypto topics
        

      user: |
        User message: {user_message}
        
        The conversation history is as follows:
        <history>
        {history}
        </history>
        Please respond to this message in a friendly, conversational manner following the guidelines above. Keep your response concise and helpful while maintaining the Token Metrics brand voice.
```

**Title:** Implement Ticket Processing for Web Agent Prompts

**Description:**  
Develop a system to capture, manage, and process tickets related to prompts for the web agent. This includes enhancing prompt engineering to improve the web agent’s responsiveness and effectiveness.

**Business Rationale:**  
Efficiently handling prompt-related tickets ensures timely resolution of issues and continuous improvement of the web agent. This leads to enhanced user satisfaction, better user interactions, and increased operational efficiency.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. A ticketing system is integrated to receive and track web agent prompt submissions.
2. Prompt engineering protocols are established and documented.
3. The web agent successfully processes prompts with a success rate of ≥95%.
4. Users can submit, view, and track the status of their tickets through the system.
5. Relevant stakeholders receive training and documentation on the new ticket processing workflow.

data.title: Column missing the available volumn
data.description:
Groomed Issue:

**Issue Title:** Add "Available Volume" Column to Trading AI Agents Dashboard

**Description:** The Trading AI Agents dashboard currently lacks the "Available Volume" column, preventing users from viewing real-time volume data. Adding this column will provide essential information for traders to assess market liquidity and make informed decisions.

**Business Rationale:** Displaying available volume is crucial for traders to evaluate market conditions and execute strategies effectively. Enhancing the dashboard with this information will improve user experience, support data-driven trading decisions, and increase the platform’s value to its users.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. The dashboard includes a new column labeled "Available Volume."
2. The "Available Volume" column accurately reflects real-time volume data from all integrated trading gateways.
3. Data in the "Available Volume" column updates automatically at least every minute.
4. The addition of the column does not degrade dashboard performance or load times.
5. Appropriate error handling is implemented to manage data retrieval issues, displaying a default message or indicator when volume data is unavailable.

data.title: Productionize the New Market Indicator
data.description:
The code produced during 2nd work trial (the market indicator that uses Supertrend) needs to be fully vectorized and refactored to be able to used in production. This ticket is about that. Deploying it using a DAG will be a follow-up ticket.

Groomed Issue:

---

**Issue Title:** Refactor and Vectorize Supertrend Market Indicator for Production

**Description:**
Optimize the Supertrend-based market indicator developed during the second work trial by fully vectorizing and refactoring the code. This enhancement is necessary to ensure the indicator is efficient, maintainable, and suitable for deployment in a production environment.

**Business Rationale:**
Transitioning the market indicator to a production-ready state will improve performance and reliability, enabling faster data processing and more accurate market analysis. This optimization supports scalable trading operations and reduces the risk of errors in live environments, ultimately contributing to better business outcomes.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. **Vectorization:** All iterative processes in the current trial code are replaced with vectorized operations to enhance performance.
2. **Refactoring:** The code is restructured for clarity, maintainability, and adherence to coding standards.
3. **Performance:** The optimized indicator demonstrates improved execution speed compared to the trial version.

---

comments.body: Unit and integration tests and documentation steps are cancelled as documentation is implied in the code.
Opened a PR to merge. Thanks as well Vasilis.
Thanks Talha! Please mark this ticket as In Review, and open a PR to merge the updated code in tm-ml-crypto
Vectorization, refactoring and performance improvements are completed. Next steps are creating solid unit and integration tests and documentation.

Conduct testing on alternative layer chains beyond the existing Base chain and Solana to assess their performance, compatibility, and scalability for integration into our platform.

Expanding support to multiple layer chains will enhance platform flexibility, attract a broader user base, and mitigate risks associated with dependency on a limited number of blockchains.

data.title: Benchmarking Join Operations for Resource Allocation
data.description:
### **Description:**

To ensure optimal performance in **StarRocks**, we need to benchmark **join operations** to determine the necessary **compute and memory resources**. This benchmarking will help identify the most efficient query execution plans, partitioning strategies, and indexing techniques required for handling large-scale joins post-migration from **Snowflake**.

---

### **Key Considerations:**

#### **1. Identifying Critical Joins for Benchmarking**

* Analyze existing **Snowflake queries** that perform complex joins.
* Identify high-impact queries based on execution time and frequency.
* Classify join types (e.g., **hash joins, nested loop joins, broadcast joins**).

#### **2. StarRocks Join Execution Strategies**

* Compare **broadcast joins vs. shuffle joins** in StarRocks.
* Evaluate how **different join algorithms** impact memory usage and execution speed.
* Determine **partitioning strategies** for optimal performance.

#### **3. Benchmarking Setup & Resource Allocation**

* Run test workloads in a controlled environment with **varying CPU & memory allocations**.
* Measure query performance under different **FE (FrontEnd) and BE (BackEnd) node configurations**.
* Identify the impact of **column pruning, dictionary encoding, and indexing** on joins.

#### **4. Performance Metrics to Capture**

* **Query latency** (before & after migration).
* **Memory & CPU usage** per query.
* **Disk I/O and shuffle cost** during joins.
* **Impact of data skew** on distributed joins.

#### **5. Optimizations & Resource Recommendations**

* Tune **FE/BE node configurations** based on benchmark results.
* Suggest **indexing strategies** to reduce join overhead.
* Determine **sufficient memory allocation per query** for stable performance.
* Recommend optimal **replication and partitioning strategies**.

parent.title: [Parent Ticket] Data migration from Snowflake to Star Rocks

comments.body:
[AI-4040](https://linear.app/token-metrics/issue/AI-4040/data-migration-from-snowflake-to-starrocks-deployment-on-kubernetes)
It's on the ticket. And I think current set up is overkilled for our needs, however just test as much as we can and we'll reduce later.

Some sql syntax in starrock is quite different with Snowflake, Also table name in starrock is `case-sensitive` (column name is `case-insentive`).  I so suggest we use all UPPERCASE for table name in starrock. cc @jake 

![image.png](https://uploads.linear.app/3973b0e9-3f84-4e56-bc80-5f55fe46609b/05341c17-fd5f-441e-af35-eee2200ab59a/eec04399-a4e7-4e57-b6aa-95ef3a196ba4)

Hi @ian, @jake , After several tests that I usually run with Snowflake, I found that Starrock adapts well to our workload and use case. Sometimes, it even performs better. The part that might take some time for me is that some SQL syntax differs between the two warehouses. It will take a bit of time to transpile the SQL scripts and test them. But overall, we're good to go with this new warehouse. @jake you can provide the configuration you're using currently and we can work together to change it optimize workload and reduce cost if needed

test3: 
build `crypto_analytics_hub_current` table
Join between 4 tables:

```
with raw_market as (
        select 
            token_id, 
            TOTAL_VOLUME AS VOLUME, 
            fully_diluted_valuation, 
            circulating_supply, 
            lag(TOTAL_VOLUME) over (partition by token_id order by date asc) as volume_previous,
            lag(fully_diluted_valuation) over (partition by token_id order by date asc) as fully_diluted_valuation_previous,
            lag(circulating_supply) over (partition by token_id order by date asc) as circulating_supply_previous,
            ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY token_id ORDER BY date DESC) as row_num
        from COINGECKO_TOKEN_PRICE_DAILY
), last_market as (
    select
        token_id,
        case 
            when volume_previous > 0 then (volume - volume_previous) / volume_previous 
        else null end volume_24h_pct_change,
        case 
            when fully_diluted_valuation_previous > 0 then (fully_diluted_valuation - fully_diluted_valuation_previous) / fully_diluted_valuation_previous 
        else null end fdv_24h_pct_change,
        case 
            when circulating_supply_previous > 0 then (circulating_supply - circulating_supply_previous) / circulating_supply_previous 
        else null end circulating_supply_24h_pct_change
    from raw_market
    where row_num = 1 
),
-- token start date
token_start_date as (
    select
        token_id,
        min(FIRST_TIMESTAMP_DAILY) as LAUNCH_DATE
    from COINGECKO_TOKEN_PRICE_DAILY
    group by token_id
)
select  
    coalesce(trader.date, investor.date) as date,
	CAST(coalesce(trader.date, investor.date) as datetime) as timestamp,

    coalesce(trader.TOKEN_URL, investor.TOKEN_URL) as TOKEN_URL,
    coalesce(trader.IS_STABLECOIN, investor.IS_STABLECOIN) as IS_STABLECOIN,
    coalesce(trader.summary, investor.summary) as summary,
    coalesce(trader.images, investor.images) as images,

    coalesce(trader.platform_details, investor.platform_details) as platform_details,
    coalesce(trader.platform_extended_details, investor.platform_extended_details) as platform_extended_details,
    coalesce(trader.explorer, investor.explorer) as explorer,
    coalesce(trader.all_time_high, investor.all_time_high) as all_time_high,
    coalesce(trader.all_time_low, investor.all_time_low) as all_time_low,
    LAUNCH_DATE,
	coalesce(TM_TRADER_GRADE,50) as TM_TRADER_GRADE,

	TM_TRADER_GRADE_24H_PCT_CHANGE,

    coalesce(TM_INVESTOR_GRADE,50) as TM_INVESTOR_GRADE,
	TM_INVESTOR_GRADE_7D_PCT_CHANGE,
	FUNDAMENTAL_GRADE,
    FUNDAMENTAL_GRADE_7D_PCT_CHANGE,
	TECHNOLOGY_GRADE,

	VALUATION_METRICS,

	MAX_DRAWDOWN,
    MAX_DRAWDOWN_PCT,
	CAGR,
```

issues.full_context:
Title: Benchmarking Join Operations for Resource Allocation

Description:
### **Description:**

To ensure optimal performance in **StarRocks**, we need to benchmark **join operations** to determine the necessary **compute and memory resources**. This benchmarking will help identify the most efficient query execution plans, partitioning strategies, and indexing techniques required for handling large-scale joins post-migration from **Snowflake**.

---

### **Key Considerations:**

#### **1. Identifying Critical Joins for Benchmarking**

* Analyze existing **Snowflake queries** that perform complex joins.
* Identify high-impact queries based on execution time and frequency.
* Classify join types (e.g., **hash joins, nested loop joins, broadcast joins**).

#### **2. StarRocks Join Execution Strategies**

* Compare **broadcast joins vs. shuffle joins** in StarRocks.
* Evaluate how **different join algorithms** impact memory usage and execution speed.
* Determine **partitioning strategies** for optimal performance.

#### **3. Benchmarking Setup & Resource Allocation**

* Run test workloads in a controlled environment with **varying CPU & memory allocations**.
* Measure query performance under different **FE (FrontEnd) and BE (BackEnd) node configurations**.
* Identify the impact of **column pruning, dictionary encoding, and indexing** on joins.

#### **4. Performance Metrics to Capture**

* **Query latency** (before & after migration).
* **Memory & CPU usage** per query.
* **Disk I/O and shuffle cost** during joins.
* **Impact of data skew** on distributed joins.

#### **5. Optimizations & Resource Recommendations**

* Tune **FE/BE node configurations** based on benchmark results.
* Suggest **indexing strategies** to reduce join overhead.
* Determine **sufficient memory allocation per query** for stable performance.
* Recommend optimal **replication and partitioning strategies**.

data.title: Develop Module to Reply to KOL tweets
data.description:
Create a list of KOLs using Kaito AI and cookie.fun apis to take the top KOLs and respond to their tweets using the X agent to help grow the agent further.

Groomed Issue:

**Title:** Develop Module for Automated Responses to KOL Tweets

**Description:**
Implement a module that identifies top Key Opinion Leaders (KOLs) using Kaito AI and cookie.fun APIs and automatically responds to their tweets via the X agent. This functionality aims to increase the agent's visibility and engagement by interacting with influential users.

**Business Rationale:**
Engaging with top KOLs can significantly enhance the agent's presence and credibility on social platforms. Automated interactions with these influential individuals can drive higher engagement rates, attract a broader audience, and facilitate the growth of the X agent by leveraging the reach and authority of KOLs.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

* Integration with Kaito AI and cookie.fun APIs to retrieve a list of top KOLs.
* The module can automatically generate and post responses to tweets from identified KOLs using the X agent.
* Responses are contextually relevant and adhere to predefined messaging guidelines.
* Logging of all interactions for monitoring and performance analysis.
* Successful deployment and testing within the V1 X TMAI Agents environment.

data.title: Use New Indicator to formulate new TM Investor Grades
data.description:
The current version of TM Investor Grade is outdated and not robust. This is apparent in the performance of the Investor Index, the performance of which deteriorates out of sample. This ticket is about using the same indicator used for the market indicator task to formulate investor grades. The scope of this ticket is to implement a production-ready pipeline. Deployment will be a follow-up ticket.

Groomed Issue:

**Title:** Rework TM Investor Grade for Enhanced Robustness

**Description:**
The existing TM Investor Grade system is outdated and lacks robustness, resulting in diminished performance of the Investor Index, especially out of sample. To improve its reliability and effectiveness, the Investor Grades will be reworked using the methodology implemented in Trader Grades v4.

**Business Rationale:**
Enhancing the TM Investor Grade will provide more accurate and reliable investor assessments, leading to better decision-making and increased trust from investors. This improvement aligns with our goal to offer robust and dependable financial tools, thereby strengthening our market position and user satisfaction.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. **Methodology Implementation:** TM Investor Grade is restructured using the Trader Grades v4 methodology.
2. **Performance Improvement:** The Investor Index shows enhanced performance both in-sample and out-of-sample tests, with no observed deterioration.
3. **Testing:** Comprehensive unit and integration tests are completed, confirming the system's robustness and accuracy.
4. **Documentation:** All relevant documentation is updated to reflect the new methodology and system changes.
5. **Stakeholder Approval:** The revised Investor Grade system is reviewed and approved by key stakeholders post-validation.

data.title: Calculate Cost for every generated tweet
data.description:
Groomed Issue:

**Title:** Implement Cost Calculation for Generated Tweets

**Description:**
Develop functionality to calculate and display the cost for each generated tweet within the platform. This feature should integrate seamlessly with the existing tweet generation system, ensuring that every tweet produced includes an accurate cost metric visible to both users and administrators.

**Business Rationale:**
Calculating the cost per generated tweet will provide transparency into operational expenses, enabling more informed pricing strategies and budget management. It will help in optimizing resource allocation, improving profitability, and offering value insights to users regarding the cost-efficiency of their tweet generation activities.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

* Each generated tweet displays a corresponding cost value.
* The cost calculation accurately accounts for all relevant factors (e.g., API usage, computation time).
* Costs are updated and reflected in real-time as tweets are generated.
* The feature is accessible to both users and administrators through the user interface.
* Comprehensive unit and integration tests are implemented to ensure the accuracy and reliability of cost calculations.

* The agent automatically responds to new posts from followed accounts with customizable messages.

* Relevant documentation is updated to include the new functionality.

data.title: API Endpoint to Retrieve and Store User Feedback
data.description:
**Title:** Implement API Endpoint to Retrieve and Store User Feedback

**Description:**
Develop a secure and efficient API endpoint for the V1 TMAI Agent Mobile App that allows users to submit their feedback and enables retrieval of existing feedback for analysis and reporting purposes.

**Business Rationale:**
Collecting user feedback is critical for understanding user satisfaction, identifying areas for improvement, and guiding future enhancements of the TMAI Agent Mobile App. By implementing this API endpoint, we facilitate structured feedback collection and analysis, leading to informed decision-making and enhanced user experience.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

* **Feedback Submission Endpoint:**
  * Accepts user feedback with necessary fields (e.g., user ID, feedback text, timestamp).
  * Validates input data and handles errors appropriately.
  * Stores feedback securely in the database.
* **Feedback Retrieval Endpoint:**
  * Allows retrieval of feedback data with support for filters such as date range and user ID.
  * Ensures only authorized personnel can access the feedback data.
* **Security:**
  * Implements authentication and authorization to protect the endpoints.
  * Ensures data is transmitted and stored securely.
* **Documentation:**
  * Provides clear API documentation detailing request and response formats.
* **Testing:**
  * Includes unit and integration tests covering all key functionalities and edge cases.
* **Performance:**
  * Ensures the endpoints respond within acceptable time frames under expected load.

More context here : [Jam | Video - https://www.perplexity.ai/search/last-10-ncaaf-championship-gam-LpmgCmVYThOL2gcQQwTQ_g](https://jam.dev/c/46ce1634-d825-4c6d-8da5-5b3e6c038bff)

comments.body: @grady this is great, good job! Are we able to make the feedback self-learning so that the prompts update as people share feedback?

# User Feedback Feature Implementation

## Overview

This PR adds a new feature for capturing user feedback from the TMAI Agent Mobile App. The implementation includes a new API endpoint for receiving feedback and storing it in a PostgreSQL database for later analysis.

## Files Changed/Created

1. **app/tmllm_main.py** - Modified to:
   * Add a new `UserFeedback` model
   * Create a new `/v2/feedback` endpoint
   * Add database integration for storing feedback
2. **app/db_setup.py** - (not pushed, for internal testing and usage only) 
   Created to:
   * Set up the database table structure
   * Verify database connectivity and table creation
   * Test database write permissions
3. **.env.example** - Created to:
   * Provide template for required environment variables

## Environment Setup

The following variables need to be added to your `.env` file:

```
# Database credentials
DB_HOST=db.qgmdcuovhxolcgrrgsgd.supabase.co
DB_PORT=5432
DB_NAME=
DB_USER=postgres
DB_PASSWORD=
```

## Implementation Details

### 1\. User Feedback Model

We added a new `UserFeedback` model with the following fields:

* `user_id`: Optional user identifier
* `user_name`: Optional user name
* `messages`: Complete conversation history at submission time
* `feedback`: The feedback text from the user
* `feedback_stage`: Indicator of when feedback was submitted:
  * `pre_response`: Before receiving an answer
  * `post_response`: After receiving an answer
* `timestamp`: When the feedback was submitted

### 2\. Database Integration

* The feedback is stored in a PostgreSQL database table called `user_feedback`
* The code includes robust error handling for database connectivity issues
* If the database is unavailable, the API will still function but will only log feedback locally

### 3\. Database Setup Script

* Created a separate script to set up and verify the database table
* The script automatically checks if the table exists and creates it if needed
* Includes testing functionality to verify write permissions

## Testing

1. **Database Setup**:
   * Run `python app/db_setup.py` to set up the database table
2. **API Endpoint**:
   * The endpoint can be tested using a POST request to `/v2/feedback`
   * Example payload:

   ```json
   {
     "user_id": 1234,
     "user_name": "Test User",
     "messages": [
       {"user": "Hello there"},
       {"chatbot": "Hello, how can I help you?"},
       {"user": "What is Bitcoin?"}
     ],
     "feedback": "The chatbot was very helpful!",
     "feedback_stage": "post_response"
   }
   ```

## Security Considerations

1. **Database Credentials**:
   * Credentials are stored in environment variables, not hardcoded
   * The implementation uses parameterized SQL queries to prevent SQL injection
2. **Error Handling**:
   * The API provides appropriate error responses for various failure scenarios
   * Database errors are not exposed to the client to prevent information leakage

## Future Enhancements

1. **Analytics**: Add functionality to analyze feedback trends
2. **Admin UI**: Create an interface for viewing and managing feedback
3. **Sentiment Analysis**: Automatically categorize feedback by sentiment (positive/negative)

data.title: Weekly Hidden Gems Curator
data.description:
Develop an AI model using Llama to curate the top project reports each week into a Hidden Gems report.

## **Context**

## Manually selecting hidden gems is subjective and time-intensive. An AI-powered curator will provide a more consistent and efficient approach to identifying promising projects.

Resources

[Token Metrics Fundamental Analysis Template](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1HPmFZcO_VWqo1uub_VC3Kc0jyjtIL4bZkwi6xuH8k7U/edit?gid=1548239995#gid=1548239995)

## **Acceptance Criteria**

* Model fine-tuned on historical Hidden Gems selections
* Automated pipeline for weekly Hidden Gems report generation
* Ranking algorithm implemented based on Token Metrics' criteria
* Natural language processing techniques applied to extract key insights from reports
* Interface for human analysts to review and adjust AI selections
* Self-hosted solution to minimize costs and maintain data control

comments.body:
Next Sprint: need to work with @ayush to define a scoring system + prompts that will let AI do the scoring on its own reliably

cc: @ian @ayush

# Proposed Comprehensive Cryptocurrency Scoring System for Hidden Gem Rankings

The following analysis presents a meticulous scoring framework for evaluating cryptocurrency projects to identify true "hidden gems" in the market. Based on the exemplary projects featured in the 2025 Crypto Hidden Gem Week 7-10 report, this scoring system provides a structured approach to assess projects across multiple dimensions, ensuring a balanced and comprehensive evaluation.

## The Foundation of Hidden Gem Evaluation

Projects like Plume Network (75.24%), Nexis AI (72.38%), and Flaunch (71.43%) demonstrate that successful crypto projects embody excellence across multiple facets. The search results reveal that these highly-rated projects combined strong technological foundations with well-designed tokenomics and clear market positioning. While the exact scoring methodology wasn't explicitly outlined in the search results, the detailed project descriptions provide valuable insights into what constitutes a promising cryptocurrency project1.

A robust crypto scoring system must account for the multifaceted nature of blockchain projects, evaluating not just the technology, but also the economic model, team quality, market potential, and other critical factors that contribute to long-term success. The system developed here transforms qualitative assessments into quantitative scores that can be compared across different projects and sectors.

## Core Evaluation Categories

The proposed scoring system divides evaluation into seven primary categories, each weighted according to its relative importance in determining a project's potential:

1. Technology and Innovation (25%)
2. Tokenomics and Utility (20%)
3. Team and Backers (15%)
4. Market Potential and Use Case (15%)
5. Security and Compliance (10%)
6. Community and Ecosystem (10%)
7. Project Maturity and Progress (5%)

This distribution ensures that while technical innovation carries significant weight, other crucial factors like tokenomics and market fit are appropriately valued. The examples from the search results demonstrate this balance – Plume Network showcased strong technical features alongside practical utility, while Nexis AI highlighted both innovative technology and strategic partnerships1.

## Category 1: Technology and Innovation (25%)

Technical innovation forms the cornerstone of valuable crypto projects, warranting the highest weight in our scoring system. This category evaluates the fundamental technological aspects that determine a project's viability and competitive advantage.

## Technical Architecture and Scalability (5 points)

The architecture evaluation examines how the blockchain or protocol is designed and its capacity to handle growing demands:

5 points: Revolutionary architecture with proven superior scalability
4 points: Highly innovative architecture with strong scalability potential
3 points: Solid architecture with reasonable scalability
2 points: Basic architecture with limited scalability improvements
1 point: Standard architecture with no significant improvements
0 points: Unproven or fundamentally flawed architecture

Nexis AI demonstrates high-scoring architecture through its "Zero-Knowledge Agentic Layer 1 infrastructure designed with EVM and SVM equivalence," supporting both scalability and privacy for data networks1.

## Innovation Level and Uniqueness (5 points)

This criterion assesses how innovative the project is compared to existing solutions:

5 points: Pioneering approach that could transform the industry
4 points: Highly novel approach with significant improvements
3 points: Meaningful innovations improving upon existing solutions
2 points: Some innovative elements but largely derivative
1 point: Minor variations on existing approaches
0 points: Direct copy of existing solutions

Plume Network's integration of real-world assets with built-in AML compliance represents an innovative approach that addresses key limitations in the RWA tokenization space1.

## Code Quality and Development Activity (5 points)

This measures both the quality of the project's codebase and ongoing development efforts:

5 points: Exceptional code quality with robust testing and active development
4 points: High-quality code with good testing and consistent development
3 points: Adequate code quality with moderate testing and regular updates
2 points: Basic code quality with minimal testing and sporadic updates
1 point: Poor code quality with little testing and infrequent updates
0 points: Critical issues in code or abandoned development

## Technological Differentiation (5 points)

This evaluates how the project's technology differentiates it from competitors:

5 points: Unique technology creating significant barriers to entry
4 points: Strong technological advantages over alternatives
3 points: Clear technological differentiation
2 points: Some differentiation but easily replicable
1 point: Minimal technological differentiation
0 points: No meaningful differentiation

The search results show NesaAI's differentiation through "zero-knowledge machine learning (ZKML) and split learning (SL)" technologies that ensure AI inference is executed securely and privately1.

## Interoperability and Standards Compliance (5 points)

This assesses how well the project works with other systems and adheres to industry standards:

5 points: Exceptional interoperability with cross-chain capabilities
4 points: Strong interoperability with multiple ecosystems
3 points: Good interoperability with relevant systems
2 points: Limited interoperability
1 point: Minimal interoperability considerations
0 points: Isolated system with no interoperability

Nexis Network demonstrates strong interoperability through its "Cross-Chain AI Interoperability" that "facilitates interaction across different blockchain networks"1.

## Category 2: Tokenomics and Utility (20%)

Tokenomics plays a crucial role in determining a project's long-term sustainability and value proposition, justifying its significant weight in the scoring system.

## Token Utility and Use Cases (5 points)

This evaluates how essential and valuable the token is within its ecosystem:

5 points: Multiple strong, essential utilities with proven demand
4 points: Several well-designed utilities adding significant value
3 points: Clear utility with demonstrable value to the ecosystem
2 points: Basic utility but limited necessity
1 point: Minimal or forced utility
0 points: No clear utility beyond speculation

In the examples, Plume's token demonstrates strong utility through its roles in "Gas Fees, Governance, Staking and Delegation, and Ecosystem Liquidity"1.

## Token Distribution and Allocation (4 points)

This assesses how fairly tokens are distributed and allocated across stakeholders:

4 points: Highly equitable distribution with appropriate allocations
3 points: Fair distribution with reasonable allocations
2 points: Acceptable distribution with some concentration concerns
1 point: Problematic distribution with significant concentration
0 points: Highly concentrated distribution favoring insiders

## Supply Mechanics and Inflation (4 points)

This evaluates the token's supply model and its impact on long-term value:

4 points: Sophisticated supply mechanisms ensuring long-term value preservation
3 points: Well-designed tokenomics with sustainable emission/burning
2 points: Reasonable supply mechanics that should maintain value
1 point: Basic supply controls with potential long-term issues
0 points: Problematic supply mechanics likely to lead to value dilution

## Value Accrual Mechanism (4 points)

This assesses how the token captures value from the protocol's success:

4 points: Strong value accrual mechanisms with multiple value drivers
3 points: Clear value accrual tied to network growth and usage
2 points: Basic value accrual mechanisms
1 point: Weak or uncertain value accrual
0 points: No clear value accrual mechanisms

An example is Flaunch's token, which enables "holders to collect up to 10% of the platform's trading fees" if a protocol-wide fee switch is activated1.

## Token Economics Alignment (3 points)

This evaluates how well token incentives align with user, investor, and ecosystem growth:

3 points: Perfect alignment of incentives across all stakeholders
2 points: Good alignment with minor conflicts
1 point: Basic incentive structure with some misalignments
0 points: Significant misalignment between stakeholders

## Category 3: Team and Backers (15%)

The quality of the team and their backers significantly influences a project's execution capabilities and resources.

## Core Team Experience and Expertise (5 points)

This assesses the team's relevant experience and capabilities:

5 points: World-class team with proven blockchain and domain expertise
4 points: Strong team with significant relevant experience
3 points: Competent team with relevant experience
2 points: Basic team capabilities with limited relevant experience
1 point: Inexperienced team or concerning background
0 points: Anonymous team with no credibility or verification

## Team Completeness and Structure (3 points)

This evaluates whether the team covers all necessary roles and expertise:

3 points: Comprehensive team covering technical, business, and operational needs
2 points: Well-rounded team with most critical roles filled
1 point: Basic team with some key gaps
0 points: Significant gaps in critical roles

## Advisory Board and Strategic Support (2 points)

This assesses the quality and relevance of advisors:

2 points: Exceptional advisors with relevant expertise and active involvement
1 point: Decent advisors with some relevant experience
0 points: No advisors or irrelevant/inactive advisors

## Investor Profile and Quality (3 points)

This evaluates the credibility and strategic value of project backers:

3 points: Top-tier investors with strategic value and strong track record
2 points: Good investors with relevant experience and connections
1 point: Basic investors or primarily retail/community funded
0 points: No disclosed investors or concerning investor background

The search results mention that "Nexis Network has successfully raised a total of $4.5 million in funding from notable investors, including Castrum Capital and Metavest Capital"1.

## Previous Track Record (2 points)

This assesses the team's previous achievements:

2 points: Proven track record of successful blockchain projects
1 point: Some relevant success or significant contributions
0 points: No track record or previous failures without learned lessons

## Category 4: Market Potential and Use Case (15%)

This category evaluates the project's market opportunity and the strength of its use case.

## Problem-Solution Fit (5 points)

This assesses how well the project addresses a genuine market need:

5 points: Addresses a critical problem with a significantly superior solution
4 points: Solves an important problem with a strong solution
3 points: Addresses a real problem with an adequate solution
2 points: Minimal problem-solution fit or addresses a trivial problem
1 point: Unclear problem or questionable solution
0 points: No clear problem or inappropriate solution

Plume Network demonstrates strong problem-solution fit by addressing real-world asset tokenization challenges with integrated compliance mechanisms1.

## Addressable Market Size (3 points)

This evaluates the potential market opportunity:

3 points: Massive addressable market with high growth trajectory
2 points: Significant market with good growth potential
1 point: Modest market or limited growth outlook
0 points: Small market or shrinking opportunity

## Competitive Landscape Positioning (3 points)

This assesses how the project positions itself against competitors:

3 points: Clear competitive advantages in an underserved market
2 points: Strong positioning with differentiating factors
1 point: Reasonable position in competitive market
0 points: Crowded market with no clear differentiation

## Go-to-Market Strategy (2 points)

This evaluates the project's plan for gaining adoption:

2 points: Comprehensive, realistic strategy with clear acquisition plan
1 point: Basic strategy with some market entry considerations
0 points: No clear strategy or unrealistic approach

## Adoption Barriers and Solutions (2 points)

This assesses potential barriers to adoption and how they're addressed:

2 points: Low adoption barriers or comprehensive solutions to overcome them
1 point: Moderate barriers with some solutions
0 points: High barriers with no clear solutions

## Category 5: Security and Compliance (10%)

Security and regulatory compliance are critical factors that can determine a project's longevity and legitimacy.

## Security Measures and Audits (4 points)

This evaluates the project's security practices:

4 points: Exceptional security with multiple audits from top firms
3 points: Strong security with at least one thorough audit
2 points: Adequate security with plans for formal audit
1 point: Basic security considerations
0 points: No security audits or significant concerns

## Regulatory Compliance Approach (3 points)

This assesses how the project addresses regulatory requirements:

3 points: Proactive compliance with legal opinions and regulatory engagement
2 points: Awareness of requirements with compliance measures
1 point: Basic consideration of regulatory issues
0 points: Ignores regulatory concerns or clearly non-compliant

Plume Network demonstrates strong compliance through "Built-In AML Compliance" that "integrates compliance mechanisms directly into its platform"1.

## Risk Assessment and Mitigation (2 points)

This evaluates how well the project identifies and addresses risks:

2 points: Thorough risk assessment with comprehensive mitigation
1 point: Basic risk awareness with some mitigation
0 points: No risk assessment or mitigation strategies

## Privacy and Data Protection (1 point)

This assesses the project's approach to privacy:

1 point: Strong privacy protection and user data control
0 points: Inadequate privacy measures or concerns

## Category 6: Community and Ecosystem (10%)

A strong community and ecosystem are essential for long-term project success and adoption.

## Community Size and Engagement (3 points)

This evaluates the project's community:

3 points: Large, highly engaged community with organic growth
2 points: Good community with active participation
1 point: Small but growing community
0 points: Minimal community or engagement concerns

## Developer Activity and Support (3 points)

This assesses developer engagement with the project:

3 points: Thriving developer ecosystem with comprehensive tools
2 points: Growing developer activity with adequate support
1 point: Early-stage developer ecosystem
0 points: No developer ecosystem or high barriers to development

## Strategic Partnerships (2 points)

This evaluates the quality and relevance of partnerships:

2 points: Multiple high-value partnerships with tangible benefits
1 point: Some relevant partnerships with potential value
0 points: No meaningful partnerships or questionable claims

## Marketing Effectiveness (2 points)

This assesses the project's marketing and communication strategy:

2 points: Strong brand recognition with effective strategy
1 point: Growing awareness with basic marketing
0 points: Poor brand presence or ineffective marketing

## Category 7: Project Maturity and Progress (5%)

This final category evaluates the project's stage of development and execution track record.

## Development Roadmap and Milestone Achievement (2 points)

This assesses the project's planning and execution:

2 points: Clear roadmap with history of meeting milestones
1 point: Reasonable roadmap with some progress
0 points: Vague roadmap or consistently missed deadlines

## Product Readiness (2 points)

This evaluates the current state of the product:

2 points: Working product with user traction
1 point: Testnet or beta with limited functionality
0 points: Concept stage only or significant delays

## Adaptability and Iteration (1 point)

This assesses the project's ability to adapt:

1 point: Demonstrated ability to improve based on feedback
0 points: Rigid approach or unresponsive to community input

## Numerical Scoring Formula and Interpretation

The final score is calculated as a weighted average of the seven category scores, using the following formula:

Final Score (%) = (Technology Score / 25 × 25%) + (Tokenomics Score / 20 × 20%) + (Team Score / 15 × 15%) + (Market Score / 15 × 15%) + (Security Score / 10 × 10%) + (Community Score / 10 × 10%) + (Maturity Score / 5 × 5%)

## Grading Scale for Hidden Gem Rankings

Based on the final percentage score, projects can be classified according to this grading scale:

90-100%: S Tier (Exceptional Hidden Gem)
80-89%: A Tier (Outstanding Potential)
70-79%: B Tier (Strong Potential)
60-69%: C Tier (Moderate Potential)
50-59%: D Tier (Speculative)
Below 50%: Not Recommended

The search results show that the top-rated projects like Plume Network (75.24%), Nexis AI (72.38%), and Flaunch (71.43%) all fall within the B Tier, indicating strong potential as hidden gems1.

## Sector-Specific Adjustments

Different cryptocurrency sectors may require specialized evaluation criteria to accurately assess their unique characteristics. The search results demonstrate this need by featuring projects from diverse sectors including RWA, Layer 1, Memecoins, and AI blockchains1.

## Layer 1 & Infrastructure Projects

For Layer 1 projects like Nexis AI and NesaAI, additional emphasis should be placed on:

* Consensus mechanism efficiency (additional 2 points)
* Network security model robustness (additional 2 points)
* Transaction throughput and finality (additional 1 point)

## Real-World Asset (RWA) Projects

RWA projects like Plume Network require evaluation of:

* Asset verification mechanisms (additional 2 points)
* Legal framework for asset ownership (additional 2 points)
* Liquidity provisions for tokenized assets (additional 1 point)

## Memecoin & Social Token Projects

For meme projects like Flaunch and Pumpkin, consider:

* Community virality potential (additional 2 points)
* Unique cultural relevance (additional 2 points)
* Trading accessibility and liquidity (additional 1 point)

## AI & ML Integration Projects

AI-focused projects like Nexis AI and NesaAI warrant assessment of:

* Data integrity and quality mechanisms (additional 2 points)
* AI model effectiveness and verification (additional 2 points)
* Computational resource optimization (additional 1 point)

## Conclusion

This comprehensive scoring system provides a robust framework for evaluating cryptocurrency projects to identify hidden gems with significant potential. By systematically assessing projects across seven critical categories, weighted according to their importance, this rubric offers a balanced and thorough evaluation methodology that can be applied across different cryptocurrency sectors.

The example projects from the search results demonstrate how this scoring approach can effectively identify promising projects by evaluating their technological innovation, tokenomics, team quality, market potential, security practices, community strength, and development progress. Such a systematic approach helps cut through the noise in the cryptocurrency market to identify projects with genuine potential for success.

For optimal results, this scoring system should be applied consistently across projects, with appropriate sector-specific adjustments to account for the unique characteristics of different types of cryptocurrency ventures. Regular reassessment is also recommended as projects evolve and market conditions change.

The way it will work be as follows:

  * Create AI-generated reports (deep dives + tech) with scores out of 100%
* Every week, pick the top 5 projects based on ratings and turn them into a Hidden Gems report

issues.full_context:
Title: Weekly Hidden Gems Curator

Description:
Develop an AI model using Llama to curate the top project reports each week into a Hidden Gems report.

## **Context**

## Manually selecting hidden gems is subjective and time-intensive. An AI-powered curator will provide a more consistent and efficient approach to identifying promising projects.

Resources

[Token Metrics Fundamental Analysis Template](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1HPmFZcO_VWqo1uub_VC3Kc0jyjtIL4bZkwi6xuH8k7U/edit?gid=1548239995#gid=1548239995)

## **Acceptance Criteria**

* Model fine-tuned on historical Hidden Gems selections
* Automated pipeline for weekly Hidden Gems report generation
* Ranking algorithm implemented based on Token Metrics' criteria
* Natural language processing techniques applied to extract key insights from reports
* Interface for human analysts to review and adjust AI selections
* Self-hosted solution to minimize costs and maintain data control

[GitHub - stanford-oval/storm: An LLM-powered knowledge curation system that researches a topic and generates a full-length report with citations.](https://github.com/stanford-oval/storm)

**Title:** Set Up Deployed Development Containers for Cross-Repository Use

**Description:**  
Establish standardized deployed development containers that can be utilized across all repositories within the tm-3.0 project. This setup will streamline the development environment setup process for team members, ensuring consistency and reducing configuration time.

**Business Rationale:**  
Addressing this technical debt will enhance development efficiency, minimize environment-related issues, and facilitate easier onboarding for new developers. Consistent development environments across repositories will lead to faster development cycles and higher code quality.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. Development containers are configured and deployed successfully.
2. All relevant repositories are updated to integrate the new dev containers.
3. Comprehensive documentation is provided for setting up and using the dev containers.
4. Verification is completed by at least two team members to ensure functionality and compatibility.

data.title: Setup self hosted Grafana
data.description:
# Task: Grafana Installation and Kubernetes Dashboard Setup

## 1\. Install Grafana on Kubernetes Cluster

### Prerequisites

* kubectl configured to access your cluster
* Helm installed

### Installation Steps

```
# Create namespace for Grafana
kubectl create namespace grafana

# Add Grafana Helm repository
helm repo add grafana https://grafana.github.io/helm-charts
helm repo update

# Install Grafana using Helm
helm install grafana grafana/grafana \
  --namespace grafana \
  --set persistence.enabled=true \
  --set persistence.size=10Gi \
  --set service.type=LoadBalancer

# Wait for external IP to be assigned
kubectl get svc -n grafana grafana -w

# Get admin password
kubectl get secret --namespace grafana grafana -o jsonpath="{.data.admin-password}" | base64 --decode ; echo
```

## 2\. Set Up Kubernetes Dashboard in Grafana

### Install Prometheus (Required for K8s Metrics)

```
# Create namespace for Prometheus
kubectl create namespace prometheus

# Install Prometheus using Helm
helm install prometheus prometheus-community/kube-prometheus-stack \
  --namespace prometheus \
  --set grafana.enabled=false
```

### Configure Kubernetes Dashboard

```
# Access Grafana UI using the external IP from earlier step
# Login with:
# Username: admin
# Password: [password from earlier step]

# Add Prometheus Data Source:
# 1. Navigate to Configuration > Data Sources
# 2. Click "Add data source"
# 3. Select "Prometheus"
# 4. Set URL to "http://prometheus-kube-prometheus-server.prometheus.svc.cluster.local:9090"
# 5. Click "Save & Test"
```

## Verification

* Grafana pod is running: `kubectl get pods -n grafana`
* Grafana service has external IP: `kubectl get svc -n grafana`
* Prometheus data source is successfully connected
* Kubernetes dashboard is displaying metrics correctly

## Next Steps

* Secure Grafana with proper authentication
* Set up additional dashboards as needed
* Configure alerting for critical metrics

data.title: Deploy social writing/hiring agent to Digital Ocean
data.description:
Groomed Issue:

**Title:** Deploy Social Writing/Hiring Agent to Digital Ocean

**Description:**
Migrate and deploy the social writing and hiring agent application to the Digital Ocean cloud platform to leverage its scalable infrastructure and enhance application performance.

**Business Rationale:**
Deploying to Digital Ocean will provide a reliable and scalable environment, reduce hosting costs, and improve the application's performance and availability. This migration supports business growth by ensuring the platform can handle increased user demand and deliver a better user experience.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. The application is successfully deployed on Digital Ocean without errors.
2. All existing features function correctly in the new environment.
3. Performance metrics meet or exceed current benchmarks post-deployment.
4. Security configurations and access controls are properly implemented.
5. Deployment and rollback procedures are documented and tested.
6. Stakeholders validate and approve the deployment.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

* All identified column issues during migration are resolved.
* Big integer columns are correctly cast without data loss.
* Implemented fixes are tested and verified.
* Successful collaboration and agreement on fixes with Andrew.
* The migrated Token Details Page functions correctly with no outstanding errors.

data.title: Anki Cycle 38 reports
data.description:
### **Milestones Achieved:**

* I have completed building the static pages for the **Trading Agent**.
* I collaborated with the **Data Team** to design a stable and unified architecture.
* I successfully migrated the entire **Rating Page logic** from **Snowflake to PostgreSQL**.
* Additionally, I implemented **Feature Flags** to ensure that migration changes do not impact the user experience.

### Next Steps:

* I will continue working on **Trading Agent V1** to ensure it functions properly and is ready for testing. This will allow us to proceed with the **launch** of this version.
* I will also verify **data accuracy** on PostgreSQL and ensure that the **latency remains within acceptable limits**.

data.title: Apply Feature-based methods to Ensure Trunk Base Development on Rating Page
data.description:
Due to supabase instability, use a feature flag to dynamically switch between Snowflake and Postgres

Groomed Issue:

**Title:** Implement Feature Flags for Trunk-Based Development on Ratings Page

**Description:**
Address the instability of Supabase by implementing feature-based methods that utilize feature flags to dynamically switch between Snowflake and Postgres for the Ratings Page. This approach ensures robust trunk-based development, enhances system reliability, and mitigates disruptions caused by database instability.

**Business Rationale:**
Switching between Snowflake and Postgres dynamically allows for greater flexibility and resilience in the Ratings Page functionality. By managing database instability through feature flags, we can maintain uninterrupted service, reduce technical debt, and improve the overall user experience.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

* Feature flags are configured to toggle between Snowflake and Postgres for the Ratings Page.
* The system can switch databases seamlessly without requiring a redeployment.
* Monitoring and alerting mechanisms are in place to track the performance and status of both databases.
* Comprehensive tests are implemented to validate the functionality of the feature flags.
* Documentation is updated to include instructions for managing and using the feature flags.

data.title: Mobile: Setup the framework to record and play audio using expo-audio or expo-av
data.description:
Groomed Issue:

**Title:** Mobile: Implement Audio Recording and Playback Framework using expo-av

**Description:**
Establish the foundational framework to enable audio recording and playback within the V1 TMAI Agent Mobile App by utilizing the expo-av library. This setup is essential for supporting the Conversational AI features, allowing users to interact through voice.

**Business Rationale:**
Integrating audio capabilities will enhance user engagement and accessibility, providing a more intuitive and hands-free interaction experience. This functionality is critical for the effective implementation of Conversational AI on mobile platforms, thereby improving overall user satisfaction and expanding the app's usability.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

* The app successfully records audio inputs from users.
* The app reliably plays back recorded audio without issues.
* The implementation utilizes the expo-av library.
* Audio features integrate seamlessly with existing Conversational AI functionalities.
* Comprehensive testing is completed on both iOS and Android devices to ensure consistent performance.

data.title: [Group] - Sentient Indices Platform Testing 5
data.description:
## Title1: Missing "Index Grade" and Key Fields in Index Details Page

**Description:**
The **"Index Grade"** field is missing from the **Index Details** page. Additionally, the following essential fields are also absent from the page:

* **No. of Tokens**
* **Average FDV**

[https://jam.dev/c/bfb584fd-4491-4574-9be2-4fde719c93c1](https://jam.dev/c/bfb584fd-4491-4574-9be2-4fde719c93c1) . Please check Figma

## **Title2:** Update Field Labels and Sorting in Index Details Page

**Description:**
There are inconsistencies between the field labels and sorting on the **Index Details** page compared to the Figma design. Specifically:

* The label **"Market Cap"** should be changed to **"Average Market Cap"**.
* The label **"24 Hour Trading Volume"** should be updated to **"24H Trading Volume"**.
* Additionally, the **sorting** on the **Index Details** page does not match the **Figma design**.
* [https://jam.dev/c/bfb584fd-4491-4574-9be2-4fde719c93c1](https://jam.dev/c/bfb584fd-4491-4574-9be2-4fde719c93c1)

## Title3: Default Selection in Index Performance Chart Should Be "Max" Instead of "1Y"

**Description:**
In the **Index Performance Chart**, the default selection is currently set to **1Y**. However, according to the **Figma design**, the default selection should be **Max** instead. This inconsistency affects the user experience, as the chart initially shows the wrong time range.

[https://jam.dev/c/af384c5a-7e5a-4aa6-ad85-82e2ab67c3fc](https://jam.dev/c/af384c5a-7e5a-4aa6-ad85-82e2ab67c3fc)

data.title: Set up Dev containers repo (github)
data.description:
Groomed Issue:

**Title:** Set Up Dev Containers Repository on GitHub

**Description:** Create a centralized GitHub repository containing standardized development container configurations to support the Engineering and AI teams. This repository will include Dockerfiles, configuration scripts, and documentation to ensure consistent and efficient setup of development environments.

**Business Rationale:** Establishing a standardized dev containers repository will reduce environment setup time, enhance consistency across teams, facilitate easier onboarding of new developers, and minimize environment-related issues, thereby increasing overall productivity and collaboration.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. A GitHub repository named "Dev-Containers" is created and accessible to both Engineering and AI teams.
2. Standardized Dockerfiles and necessary configuration scripts are included in the repository.
3. Comprehensive documentation is provided, detailing setup and customization procedures.
4. At least two teams have successfully set up their development environments using the repository configurations.
5. The repository is version-controlled and maintenance procedures are established for future updates.

data.title: error approving tmai
data.description:
hi i cant stake havi
ng issue error approving tmai

Groomed Issue:

**Title:** Error Approving TMAI Prevents Staking of HAVI

**Description:**
Users are experiencing errors when attempting to approve TMAI, which blocks them from staking HAVI tokens. This issue disrupts the staking process and hinders user participation.

**Business Rationale:**
Ensuring the approval and staking functionalities work seamlessly is essential for user engagement and the overall health of the platform’s ecosystem. Resolving this issue will enhance user satisfaction and maintain trust in our staking services.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

* Users can successfully approve TMAI without encountering errors.
* Users are able to stake HAVI tokens after TMAI approval.
* The approval and staking processes execute smoothly across all supported browsers and devices.
* Comprehensive testing confirms the resolution of the error.

data.title: [Group] - Sentient Indices Platform Testing 4
data.description:
## **Title1:**Tokens Bought is 0 for Some Coins in **Last Index Transactions**

**Description:**
The Tokens Bought data is 0 for some coins in the **Last Index Transactions** section. This results in incomplete data for certain coins, which could confuse users or prevent them from making informed decisions.

[https://jam.dev/c/d4e02caf-9972-4eb7-a78b-35a9a2479208](https://jam.dev/c/d4e02caf-9972-4eb7-a78b-35a9a2479208)

## **Title2:** Inconsistent Design for "Search Tokens" and "Search Indices" Search Buttons

**Description:**
The designs for the **"Search Tokens"** and **"Search Indices"** search buttons are different These buttons should have a consistent design to ensure a unified user experience and improve the overall UI consistency.

[https://jam.dev/c/30b1de19-d8e1-47ae-ab59-f91886d39bd4](https://jam.dev/c/30b1de19-d8e1-47ae-ab59-f91886d39bd4)

## **Title3:** "Investor Index" and "Price Performance" Sections Should Be Fixed on Scroll

**Description:**
The **"Investor Index"** and **"Price Performance"** sections on the left side of the page should remain **fixed** when scrolling down. Currently, these sections scroll away with the page, which makes it difficult for users to refer to them while exploring other content on the page.

[https://jam.dev/c/e8517a01-b45f-4513-bd9b-9e9f0127648b](https://jam.dev/c/e8517a01-b45f-4513-bd9b-9e9f0127648b)

## Title4: There is no tooltip for Index Selection

[https://jam.dev/c/3938fa3a-ad2b-49e2-82ac-e0f2cabd64ab](https://jam.dev/c/3938fa3a-ad2b-49e2-82ac-e0f2cabd64ab). Could you send the tooltip detail?

## Title5: Sorting Not Available for "Top Gainer" Column in All Indices Table

**Description:**
In the **All Indices** table, the **"Top Gainer"** column does not have sorting functionality, and users cannot sort the data in this column. We need to evaluate whether sorting is necessary for this column or if the current behavior is appropriate. @ayo Do we need to sort Top Gainer?

[https://jam.dev/c/ab2018b5-b5a3-4c4f-91f3-4dadf50389d5](https://jam.dev/c/ab2018b5-b5a3-4c4f-91f3-4dadf50389d5)

## Title6: Token Count Showing 10 for All Indices

**Description:**
The **Token Count** for all indices is displayed as **10**, but it is unclear whether this is the correct number for every index. We need to verify if the **Token Count** should always be 10 for each index, or if this is an issue with how the data is being retrieved or displayed.

[https://jam.dev/c/a2a0f35b-8ea8-40a9-9499-402b0e4fbe54](https://jam.dev/c/a2a0f35b-8ea8-40a9-9499-402b0e4fbe54)

## Title7: Data Units and Clarity Missing in Indices Price History Chart

**Description:**
In the **Indices Price History** chart, the displayed data is unclear, and it is not specified which **unit** the data is in (e.g., price, percentage, or other metrics). Additionally, it's uncertain if the data display format is correct. This makes it difficult for users to interpret the chart accurately. @ayo 

[https://jam.dev/c/7afe878c-622d-44b2-851b-e769835397d5](https://jam.dev/c/7afe878c-622d-44b2-851b-e769835397d5)

## **Title8:** "Buy Token" Button Unclickable Due to Layout Shift

**Description:**
The **"Buy Token"** button is not clickable because its position shifts unexpectedly, preventing users from interacting with it. This issue is likely due to layout changes or misalignment of the button on the page.

[https://jam.dev/c/359601f4-ba55-4284-b989-78cfe21d7d19](https://jam.dev/c/359601f4-ba55-4284-b989-78cfe21d7d19)

## Title9: Default Selection in Index Performance Chart Should Be "Max" Instead of "1Y"

**Description:**
In the **Index Performance Chart**, the default selection is currently set to **1Y**. However, according to the **Figma design**, the default selection should be **Max** instead. This inconsistency affects the user experience, as the chart initially shows the wrong time range.

[https://jam.dev/c/af384c5a-7e5a-4aa6-ad85-82e2ab67c3fc](https://jam.dev/c/af384c5a-7e5a-4aa6-ad85-82e2ab67c3fc)
