data.title: Annotation and Feedback Routine for Chatbot Responses - Cycle 38
data.description:
**Description:** To improve the chatbot's accuracy and usefulness, allocate an hour each week for reviewing and annotating its responses. This involves providing constructive feedback on chatbot answers, identifying areas for improvement, and submitting annotated examples via **LangSmith**

for an overview on giving feedback to the chatbot answers to make them more useful (annotating). It will really help with our fine tuning

### **Steps to Implement:**

1. **Weekly Feedback Routine:**
   * Schedule a dedicated hour each week for annotation and feedback.l).

* Evaluate the answers for:
  * Accuracy
  * Clarity
  * Relevance
  * Completeness
* Annotate suggestions or corrections for improvements directly in LangSmith.

1. **Annotating Responses:**
   * Highlight areas where the response is incorrect, vague, or incomplete.
   * Mark high-quality responses as examples of best practices.
   * Example: [https://jam.dev/c/a410f1f8-42fd-46c0-a7c8-5a0420eba9a6](https://jam.dev/c/a410f1f8-42fd-46c0-a7c8-5a0420eba9a6)
   * [https://jam.dev/c/fe976069-9934-4fa0-a7f3-6155ab09bf3d](https://jam.dev/c/fe976069-9934-4fa0-a7f3-6155ab09bf3d)

**Issue: Testing & QA for On-Chain Swaps Ratings, Indices, and Token Details**

**Description:**   Perform comprehensive testing and quality assurance for the on-chain swaps feature, specifically focusing on ratings, indices, and token details. Collaborate with the Marketing team to ensure readiness for production deployment.

**Business Rationale:**   Ensuring the reliability and accuracy of on-chain swap functionalities is essential for maintaining user trust and platform integrity. Effective QA will minimize bugs, enhance user experience, and support a successful market launch through coordinated marketing efforts.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

* All on-chain swap features related to ratings, Governance, and token details pass predefined test cases without critical issues.
* Successful integration and collaboration with the Marketing team for launch strategies.
* Comprehensive QA documentation is completed and reviewed.
* Production readiness is confirmed and approved by both QA and Marketing teams.

data.title: Meeting Logs
data.description:
---

1. **Standup (Daily)**
   * Time: 15 mins
2. **1-on-1 with Team Mates (Daily)**
   * Time: 20-25 mins
3. **Sprint Demo (Weekly)**
   * Time: 1 hr
4. **Sprint Retro (Weekly)**
   * Time: 1 hr
   * Sprint Planning - 2hr
5.  Work Trail
       1hr

---

Groomed Issue:

---

**Title:** Document and Optimize Yogendra's Meeting Schedule

**Description:**
Create a comprehensive log of Yogendra's recurring meetings, including:

1. **Standup (Daily)** – 15 minutes
2. **1-on-1 with Team Mates (Daily)** – 20-25 minutes
3. **Sprint Demo (Weekly)** – 1 hour
4. **Sprint Retro (Weekly)** – 1 hour

Analyze the current schedule to identify opportunities for improving efficiency and time management.

data.title: Setup trigger dev for DATA API CRON
data.description:
We have a CRON job that resets user monthly limits for the DATA API. We need to integrate it with Trigger.dev to ensure we get notified if something breaks.

Groomed Issue:

**Title:** Integrate Trigger.dev Monitoring for DATA API CRON Job

**Description:**
Implement Trigger.dev integration for the DATA API CRON job that resets user monthly limits. This will enable real-time notifications in case the CRON job fails or encounters issues, ensuring prompt awareness and response to any disruptions.

**Business Rationale:**
Maintaining the reliability of the monthly limit resets is essential for user satisfaction and the overall functionality of the DATA API. By integrating with Trigger.dev, the team can proactively monitor the CRON job, quickly identify failures, and minimize potential negative impacts on users.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

* The DATA API CRON job is successfully integrated with Trigger.dev.
* Notifications are configured and tested to trigger on CRON job failures or errors.
* Successful executions of the CRON job generate appropriate success notifications.
* Documentation is updated to include the Trigger.dev integration details.
* Verification that notifications are received correctly by simulating both successful runs and failures of the CRON job.

data.title: Import Current tm-airflow-cluster-dev AI cluster as a data so it can be fully managed by Terraform
data.description:
Currently, the tm-airflow-cluster-dev AI cluster on Google Cloud Platform is managed outside of our Terraform infrastructure. This task involves importing the existing cluster as a Terraform resource so it can be fully managed through our Infrastructure as Code (IaC) pipeline using our existing Terraform repository.

## Objective

Enable complete Terraform management of the existing GCP tm-airflow-cluster-dev AI cluster without rebuilding or disrupting the service.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [X] Identify all GCP resources and configurations associated with tm-airflow-cluster-dev
- [X] Create appropriate Terraform configuration files in the tm3-devops repository
- [X] Successfully import the cluster into Terraform state
- [X] Verify no unintended modifications by running terraform plan
- [X] Submit a pull request to the tm3-devops repository with changes
- [X] Update documentation to reflect the new management method

## Technical Details

* **Environment**: Development
* **Target Resource**: tm-airflow-cluster-dev AI cluster on GCP
* **Repository**: [https://github.com/token-metrics/tm3-devops](https://github.com/token-metrics/tm3-devops)
* **Tools Required**: Terraform CLI, Google Cloud SDK

## Implementation Steps

1. Clone the tm3-devops repository
2. Identify the appropriate resource type for the AI cluster in GCP
3. Create or update relevant Terraform configuration files
4. Run `terraform import` commands to bring existing resources under management
5. Test with `terraform plan` to ensure no destructive changes
6. Submit PR for review

## Dependencies

* Access to GCP project containing the cluster
* Proper permissions to view and manage the cluster
* Write access to the tm3-devops repository

   * Post-change analytics confirm increased click-through and improved user engagement.

data.title: Update query for Most Trending Tokens on website
data.description:
@vasilis said:

> @ahmedhamdy @harshg Below is the query we need to start using to get the `Most Trending Tokens`, in both the website and the X agent :
>
> ```
> SELECT 
>     trending_tokens.*,
>     lastest_market_price_tokens.last_updated
> FROM CRYPTO_DB.COINGECKO.COINGECKO_TRENDING_TOKENS as trending_tokens
> JOIN CRYPTO_DB.COINGECKO.COINGECKO_LATEST_PRICE_FRONTEND_VIEW as lastest_market_price_tokens
> ON trending_tokens.cg_id = lastest_market_price_tokens.coingecko_id
> ORDER BY lastest_market_price_tokens.last_updated DESC;
> ```
>
> It ranks by `last_updated` to be consistent between the website and the X agent. Please update your end so that both parts are on par. Thanks!

data.title: Review the whole codebase and architecture and suggest improvements
data.description:
Groomed Issue:

**Issue: Codebase and Architecture Review for Improvement**

**Description:**
Conduct a comprehensive evaluation of the entire codebase and system architecture to identify areas for enhancement. Provide actionable recommendations to improve performance, maintainability, scalability, and security.

**Business Rationale:**
Optimizing the codebase and architecture ensures the application remains robust and efficient, reduces technical debt, and supports future growth. Enhancements will lead to better user experiences, lower maintenance costs, and increased ability to adapt to evolving business needs.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. Detailed documentation of the current codebase and architecture.
2. Identification of at least three key areas for improvement with clear justifications.
3. Actionable recommendations prioritized by impact and feasibility.
4. An implementation roadmap outlining the steps to address the recommended improvements.

comments.body:
Based on my observations of our TM3.0  codebase, I've identified a couple of areas that could be improved:

**Dependency optimisation:** I've noticed we have around 100 dependencies in TM3.0. One specific improvement we've already discussed is switching from react-icons to l`ucide-icons` (referenced in the issue. [ENG-4647](https://linear.app/token-metrics/issue/ENG-4647/review-the-local-development-experience-for-tm-30) ). We should continue ao analyse ur dependency tree to find other optimisation opportunities.

A**rchitecture Evolution**: As our application and team continue to grow, we might want to explore approaches like Micro-Frontends or Next.js Multi-zones ([https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/deploying/multi-zones](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/deploying/multi-zones)). This would complement our existing microservices backend architecture and help with team scalability and deployment independence.

These observations are preliminary based on challenges I've faced while working with the codebase. I think we should have further team discussions to evaluate the impact and feasibility of these approaches before making major architectural decisions.
@suleman Pls put an estimate for this.

comments.body: @yogendra sent you Cloudflare invite to email
@ian It would be great if you could share the user(account) for Cloudflare to check the visibility.
@ian We can check the option for using Cloudflare … Let me look into this further to see if there’s a viable way to leverage it.
@yogendra thats good. Can we do it via Cloudflare cloud? We have $250k in free credits we want to use.

@ian I set up a free tier AWS EC2 G5.2x instance for running some performance analysis. Just to clarify, this setup isn't for deployment or development; I'm using it mainly to test out how things perform. Think of it as a way to get access to a high-performance machine without having to buy one—it's basically renting the resource. We could also do something similar with GCP if we want to rent instances for local development. This gives us the flexibility to use powerful machines without the upfront costs while we work locally with VS Code.
@yogendra we currently use EC2? I thought we were using GCP and Vercel?

### Detailed Feedback and Comparison

1. **EC2 Instance Allocation**:
   * I have allocated full capacity on our EC2 instance (C5.4xlarge) with a total of 32GB RAM. This allocation has demonstrated a noticeable performance gain, improving build times from `6:33` to `5:39`, resulting in a time gain of 54 seconds (approximately 14.5%).
2. **Baseline Machine Consideration**:
   * When evaluating the performance of our code base, a baseline machine configuration should ideally be similar to the Mac M2 with 24GB RAM. This configuration provides a reasonable balance between performance and resource availability, ensuring that our code runs effectively without hitting memory constraints.
3. **Library Changes and Optimization**:
   * While changing libraries can lead to potential performance gains (e.g., removing React-Icons returned a 35% faster build time), it is crucial to maintain a bare minimum machine specification. Even with optimization efforts, operating on lower-spec systems (e.g., machines with only 12GB of RAM) could lead to build instability and increased build times.
4. **Comparative Gains**:
   * The various approaches we are considering include:
     * **Library Removal**: Approx. 35% faster builds by eliminating unnecessary dependencies.
     * **Code Optimization**: Streamlined code can further enhance performance, but exact gains depend on the specific changes made.
     * **EC2 High-RAM Allocation**: 14.5% faster builds observed with maximum RAM allocation, which shows that moving to a stronger infrastructure can yield significant time savings.
     * **Maintaining Minimum Specifications**: Keeping a machine like the M2 (24GB) as the baseline helps to ensure reliable performance across all environments.

In summary, each approach has its own benefits that we need to consider in relation to our performance goals. Utilizing an EC2 instance with robust configurations can be a practical solution, especially if we can't allocate similar machines locally. Connecting to EC2 servers from our local setup offers a quick and efficient way to leverage better resources. However, it’s still important to maintain a minimum specification baseline to ensure stable performance. As we work on optimizing our code and libraries, this balance will help us achieve better operational efficiency.

CC @suleman @ian

@faith, please note the React-icon library we're using is slowing down the site. 

Do we really need it? Could you review these other recommended options from Grok3?

Since you’re focused on optimizing build time with tree-shaking, here are the best icon libraries for a React project that natively support it, keeping your bundles lean and fast. Tree-shaking ensures only the icons you import end up in the final build, cutting out unused code—a must for performance.

1. **Tabler Icons** npm: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@tabler/icons-react | GitHub: https://github.com/tabler/tabler-icons | Website: https://tabler-icons.io/
   * **Why it’s great**: Over 2,000 clean, modern SVG icons as individual React components. Tree-shaking is built-in, so importing IconHome only bundles that icon. It’s lightweight and consistently fast—think 6-13 seconds for thousands of icons in a modern bundler like Vite or Webpack.
   * **Setup**: npm install @tabler/icons-react, then import { IconHome } from '@tabler/icons-react';.
   * **Best for**: Teams wanting a balance of variety and speed without extra config.
2. **Feather Icons** (npm: https://www.npmjs.com/package/react-feather | GitHub: https://github.com/feathericons/react-feather | Website: https://feathericons.com/)
   * **Why it’s great**: Super lightweight with 287 minimalistic SVG icons. Like Tabler, it’s tree-shakeable by default—only the icons you import (e.g., import { Home } from 'react-feather';) make it into the build. Its small size means even quicker compiles than larger libraries.
   * **Setup**: npm install react-feather.
   * **Best for**: Projects needing a smaller, curated set of icons with minimal overhead.
3. **Heroicons** (npm: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@heroicons/react | GitHub: https://github.com/tailwindlabs/heroicons | Website: https://heroicons.com/)
   * **Why it’s great**: Offers \~450 icons in two styles (outline and solid), optimized for React with tree-shaking. Maintained by the Tailwind Labs team, it’s a solid choice if you’re already in that ecosystem. Build times stay snappy since unused icons are stripped out.
   * **Setup**: npm install @heroicons/react, then import { HomeIcon } from '@heroicons/react/24/solid';.
   * **Best for**: Tailwind users or teams wanting polished icons with moderate variety.
4. **Phosphor Icons** (npm: https://www.npmjs.com/package/phosphor-react | GitHub: https://github.com/phosphor-icons/phosphor-react | Website: https://phosphoricons.com/)
   * **Why it’s great**: A hefty 6,000+ icons with multiple weights (thin, regular, bold, etc.), all tree-shakeable. It’s more extensive than Tabler but still keeps builds efficient by only including what you use. Slightly heavier than Feather or Heroicons, but versatile.
   * **Setup**: npm install phosphor-react, then import { House } from 'phosphor-react';.
   * **Best for**: Projects needing a huge icon range without sacrificing build performance.

Compared to **react-icons**, which bundles multiple icon sets and can bloat builds even with tree-shaking (due to its size and less granular imports), these options are purpose-built for efficiency. **Tabler** or **Feather** are my top picks for speed-focused teams—Tabler if you need more icons, Feather if you can work with fewer. Test one in your project with your bundler (Vite, Webpack, etc.) and check the build stats. 

cc: @suleman @yogendra
@yogendra that's great, how about trying to do the same with `highcharts`, `echarts` and `ccxt` libraries to see what more improvements do we see.

After testing the React-Icons removal, I'm seeing some impressive speed gains on my M2 Pro Mac:

**Before (with React-Icons)**

* Build time: 6min 5sec
* CPU usage was pretty high at 175%

**After (React-Icons removed)**

* Build time: 3min 55sec
* CPU usage dropped to 159%
  
  `With React-Icons `

  `26 Feb 2025→ 8:13PM IST→ Yogendra Singh Mac M2 Pro Build Time and Utilization:- `

  `npm run build  555.01s user 87.53s system 175% cpu 6:05.29 total`

  
  
  `After Removed React-Icons `

  `26 Feb 2025→ 9:36PM IST→ Yogendra Singh Mac M2 Pro Build Time and Utilization:- `

  `npm run build  334.20s user 40.48s system 159% cpu 3:55.07 total`

That's over 2 minutes saved on every build (35% faster)! The system is also working less hard - user processing time dropped by almost 40% and system time by more than half.

I would love to see the stats on other machine too please follow these steps:- 

1. Checkout staging and run `time npm run build` to get your baseline
2. Try branch [ENG-4647](https://linear.app/token-metrics/issue/ENG-4647/review-the-local-development-experience-for-tm-30) with a fresh `npm install`
3. Run the build again and compare

If you test this, I'd love to hear your results, especially on Windows or lower-spec machines!

Full details in the docs and Please add yours performance: [https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xPrtugNxHv1n774o2D7i1UN82nNGGQIzedDXGtJiNFo/edit?tab=t.0](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xPrtugNxHv1n774o2D7i1UN82nNGGQIzedDXGtJiNFo/edit?tab=t.0)

FYI:- @suleman

Yes, we can try this approach since it looks like we're using `react-icons` in many places (181 files). The size difference is significant - `react-icons` (86.2MB) is more than double the size of `lucide-react` (32.87MB), which can be one of the reasdon  why our builds require so much memory.


Maybe this could work in our case, create a utility function that maps common `react-icons` to their lucid equivalents, then gradually replace them component by component, starting with the most icon-heavy files.

Let's catch up over a call and discuss the details and potential impact. While `react-icons` offer more variety, switching to `lucide-react` could substantially improve build performance and development experience.

@yogendra It actually needs even more than 4GB memory, if you see the build script we allocate it around 12GB memory for build to be successful. Regarding the analyzer we already did that and found out `react-icons` and some charting libraries are taking some space that we can remove or replace. 

The main issue here is even if these libraries are present they just consume some space maybe a few MBs in final build bundle, then why during processing of the build it consumes this much memory when final bundle size is nowhere near 8-12GB? This means during the actual build it does something specific which consumes alot of memory. It's like processing a video which is 100MB in size itself but processing it in an editing software takes 12GB of RAM.

Though I want to initially go for an option of removing the `react-icons` library and then trying to build again to see how much memory consumption difference we see. The issue is this library is used in around 181 files within our repo, so even commenting it out for testing would take a lot of time. I tried with AI tools as well but due to context size being too big they also fail and start doing strange stuff after editing 10-20 files. If you have bandwidth you can try it and we can discuss the impact of that, if we see improvements then we'll focus on removing it entirely and using `lucide-react` which is already present or some other library which is smaller in size. Then we can proceed with charting libraries and do the same thing.

What's your suggestion/opinion on this?

Based on my initial investigation:

I found that TM 3.0 requires about 4GB of RAM just to build! This explains why developers with less memory are experiencing crashes.

Here is the Key point:-

**\[52508:0x150008000\]   129038 ms: Mark-Compact 4021.1 (4138.7) -> 4008.0 (4141.5) MB, 1071.17 / 0.00 ms  (average mu = 0.056, current mu = 0.020) allocation failure; scavenge might not succeed**

When running the analyzer on my M2 Mac (24GB RAM), I noticed the build process attempting to use over 4GB before failing with a memory allocation error. The full logs are available here: [https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xPrtugNxHv1n774o2D7i1UN82nNGGQIzedDXGtJiNFo/edit?addon_store&tab=t.0](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xPrtugNxHv1n774o2D7i1UN82nNGGQIzedDXGtJiNFo/edit?addon_store&tab=t.0)

Next steps:

1. Run the analyzer on machines with less RAM (16GB or less)
2. Check available memory during the build process
3. Monitor which components are causing memory spikes

If you'd like to help, please check out PR #6152 ([https://github.com/token-metrics/tokenmetrics-3.0/pull/6152](https://github.com/token-metrics/tokenmetrics-3.0/pull/6152)), run `npm run analyze`, and share your system specs with the results.

CC: @suleman

For investigation, we can start with these 2 tests:

1. Bundle analysis to identify memory-intensive dependencies
   * Run the analyzer to find large modules consuming excessive memory
   * Focus on dependencies larger than 250KB
2. Webpack configuration optimization
   * Modify development mode settings to reduce memory usage
   * Disable non-essential features on Windows machines
This issue has been reviewed and updated using AI.
This comment thread is synced to a corresponding [GitHub issue](https://github.com/token-metrics/tokenmetrics-3.0/issues/6143). All replies are displayed in both locations.

Title: Review the local development experience for TM-3.0

Description:
Groomed Issue:

**Title:** Improve Local Development Experience for [TM-3](https://linear.app/token-metrics/issue/TM-3/test-tokenlist-on-tm-development-website).0

**Description:** Assess and enhance the local development environment for [TM-3](https://linear.app/token-metrics/issue/TM-3/test-tokenlist-on-tm-development-website).0 to streamline setup processes, reduce technical debt, and facilitate a more efficient workflow for developers.

**Business Rationale:** Optimizing the local development experience will decrease onboarding time, minimize errors, and boost developer productivity. This leads to faster feature development, higher code quality, and ultimately a more competitive product in the market.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. Complete evaluation of the current local development setup.
2. Identify and document key pain points and areas of technical debt.
3. Propose and implement at least three improvements to the development workflow.
4. Validate enhancements by reducing setup time by 30% and receiving positive feedback from at least 80% of the development team.

data.title: [Group] - Sentient Indices Platform Testing 2
data.description:
### **Title1: Missing Icons for Some Coins (e.g., Polyhedra)**

**Summary:**
Some coins, such as **Polyhedra**, are missing their **icons** in the UI, leading to inconsistent visuals and making it harder to identify them.

[https://jam.dev/c/5dac0b88-34e6-4d50-b857-df53ee4fd131](https://jam.dev/c/5dac0b88-34e6-4d50-b857-df53ee4fd131)

### **Title2: Missing Tooltips in "Last Index Transactions" Table Headers**

**Summary:**
The **"Last Index Transactions"** table does not have tooltips for its column headers, making it unclear what each column represents

[https://jam.dev/c/39d68c02-bf12-40c8-87bb-b67f1b26bec8](https://jam.dev/c/39d68c02-bf12-40c8-87bb-b67f1b26bec8)

### **Title3: Back Button Not Working on Similar Indices Detail Page**

**Summary:**
When navigating to a **token detail page** from the **Similar Indices** section, the **Back button does not work**, preventing users from returning to the previous page.

[https://jam.dev/c/201f2ca6-33e9-4318-a0e6-4e558052f554](https://jam.dev/c/201f2ca6-33e9-4318-a0e6-4e558052f554)

### **Title4: Token Abbreviation Missing Next to Token Name in Index Transactions**

**Summary:**
In the **Index Transactions** section, the **token abbreviation** should be displayed **next to the token name**, as shown in the **Figma design**

[https://jam.dev/c/63728717-4c90-4aa2-bf32-48115982a21a](https://jam.dev/c/63728717-4c90-4aa2-bf32-48115982a21a)

[https://jam.dev/c/de526841-3e52-4bcf-a6d0-fa40cc5237e6](https://jam.dev/c/de526841-3e52-4bcf-a6d0-fa40cc5237e6)

### **Title5: Incorrect Alignment and Missing Time in Index Performance Chart**

**Summary:**
In the **Index Performance Chart**, when hovering over the chart:

1. The **Date and Index values** are **not properly aligned** 
2. The tooltip **only displays the date**, but **time information is missing**, whereas the **Figma design includes both date and time**.
3. [https://jam.dev/c/00973b85-52d8-42fb-ad82-87160e524b2d](https://jam.dev/c/00973b85-52d8-42fb-ad82-87160e524b2d)

### **Title6: "Some Crypto Assets May Not Be Available" Text is Misaligned in Mobile View**

**Summary:**
The **"Some crypto assets may not be available"** text is **misaligned or broken** in mobile view, affecting readability and UI consistency.

[https://jam.dev/c/46b3722b-5813-4e81-9cc9-f31a9e739eb5](https://jam.dev/c/46b3722b-5813-4e81-9cc9-f31a9e739eb5)

### **Title7: Index Performance Chart Overlaps with Price Performance Table When Scrolling Up in Mobile View**

**Summary:**
When scrolling up, the **Index Performance Chart** overlaps with the **Price Performance** table, causing a UI conflict and making the data difficult to read.

[https://jam.dev/c/62d962a5-7ec5-4673-981a-207e28ac6c70](https://jam.dev/c/62d962a5-7ec5-4673-981a-207e28ac6c70)

### **Title8: "Buy Index" Button Not Working in Mobile View**

**Summary:**
In **mobile view**, the **"Buy Index"** button is **not working**, preventing users from proceeding with purchases.

[https://jam.dev/c/f9c5a52a-7693-4444-a3a5-a1ede90918bb](https://jam.dev/c/f9c5a52a-7693-4444-a3a5-a1ede90918bb)

### **Title9: "Buy Token" Popup Not Appearing in Token Treemap View**

**Summary:**
In the **Token Treemap View**, clicking on a token does not trigger the **"Buy Token"** popup, preventing users from making purchases.

Figma Expected: [https://jam.dev/c/cd748ee6-22d6-4e97-985f-b8a92d49418b](https://jam.dev/c/cd748ee6-22d6-4e97-985f-b8a92d49418b)

Actual Result: [https://jam.dev/c/b4130094-da5c-4ba6-9882-89f2d181f418](https://jam.dev/c/b4130094-da5c-4ba6-9882-89f2d181f418)

### **Title10: Values in Index Details Overflowing Outside the Index Details Section**

**Summary:**
In the **Index Details** section, some values **overflow outside** the designated area, causing **layout breakage** and **misalignment** of elements.

[https://jam.dev/c/0b4ce2d6-4e69-444b-b907-f19d030551d7](https://jam.dev/c/0b4ce2d6-4e69-444b-b907-f19d030551d7)

### **Title11: AI Indices Details Page** `index=undefined`

**Summary:**
When trying to navigate to an **Index Details** page, the **URL incorrectly includes** `index=undefined`, leading to a **broken page and missing data**.

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Open the **AI Indices** page.
2. Click on any **index** to view its details.
3. We can not see details
4. [https://jam.dev/c/22c45028-58d8-452b-ad00-4dca6f3d23e4](https://jam.dev/c/22c45028-58d8-452b-ad00-4dca6f3d23e4)

---

data.title: Resolve Sentry Bugs Using AI-Powered Autofix
data.description:
Leverage Sentry's AI-powered Autofix to efficiently resolve our backlog of medium to high priority issues. 

[tokenmetrics-30.sentry.io](https://tokenmetrics-30.sentry.io/issues/?project=4505918249566208&query=is:unresolved%2520issue.priority:%255Bhigh,%2520medium%255D&sort=date&statsPeriod=30d&viewId=default0)

## Tasks:

1. Enable Sentry AI Autofix
2. Prioritize medium-high severity Sentry issues
3. For each issue:
   * Run Autofix analysis
   * Review generated fix and PR
   * Approve or modify changes
   * Merge and deploy
4. Monitor resolved issues

## Implementation Guide:

1. Access issue details in Sentry
2. Click "Open Autofix" in Solutions Hub
3. Provide additional context (optional)
4. Review Autofix assessment and plan
5. Examine PR and unit tests
6. Approve or request changes

## Acceptance Criteria

1. All Sentry bugs are resolved
2. Accompanying Jam Dev and documentation on the changes done and what not to do going forward.

## Key Resources:

* Docs: [https://docs.sentry.io/product/issues/issue-details/sentry-ai/](https://docs.sentry.io/product/issues/issue-details/sentry-ai/)
* Tutorial: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-e5R8RnHt-s](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-e5R8RnHt-s)
* Blog: [https://bit.ly/ai-blog-lw2](https://bit.ly/ai-blog-lw2)

This streamlined approach will help us quickly address our issue backlog while maintaining code quality.

data.title: TokenMetrics 3.0 Scaling issue
data.description:
Groomed Issue:

**Title:** TokenMetrics 3.0 Scaling Issue

**Description:**
TokenMetrics 3.0 is encountering scalability challenges that cause performance slowdowns during peak usage periods. Addressing this issue is essential to ensure the platform remains responsive and reliable as the user base grows.

**Business Rationale:**
Maintaining optimal performance is critical for user satisfaction and retention. By resolving the scaling issues, we can support increased user demand, prevent potential revenue loss from downtime, and facilitate the platform’s growth objectives.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

* The system supports a 200% increase in concurrent users without measurable performance degradation.
* Average response times are maintained below 2 seconds during peak load.
* Automated scaling mechanisms are implemented and successfully tested.
* Comprehensive load testing is completed, meeting all predefined performance benchmarks.
* Documentation is updated to reflect the changes and scalability improvements.

data.title: Review and Address Vulnerabilities in Token Metrics Projects
data.description:
Review and prioritize security vulnerabilities across Token Metrics projects, focusing on high-severity issues.

## Priority Items

1. Address the 72 high-severity vulnerabilities in token-metrics/tm-data-engineering
2. Review the 90 medium-severity issues in token-metrics/data-api-express
3. Investigate the 18 high-severity vulnerabilities in token-metrics/tm-ml-chat

## Action Steps

* Use the Snyk dashboard to review vulnerability details
* Group vulnerabilities by target using the filter option
* Address critical (C) vulnerabilities first (6 in data-engineering, 5 in tokenmetrics-3.0)
* Document remediation steps in the project repository
* Set up regular review cycles for new vulnerabilities

## Resources

* Snyk dashboard access
* Project documentation in respective repositories
* View import logs for detailed vulnerability information

![image.png](https://uploads.linear.app/3973b0e9-3f84-4e56-bc80-5f55fe46609b/96f21f8d-98a4-4980-92e7-0dc6cf0d349a/12c51074-f972-44b4-b765-d9d125598655)

[https://app.snyk.io/org/tokenmetrics](https://app.snyk.io/org/tokenmetrics/?fromGitHubAuth=true) - task url

comments.body:
![image.png](https://uploads.linear.app/3973b0e9-3f84-4e56-bc80-5f55fe46609b/ae253549-4208-4d1f-b34b-837ea4d96748/c451fcbb-6a58-4868-9989-043557dbbb4c)

I've reviewed the security vulnerabilities across the Token Metrics projects using the Snyk dashboard, prioritizing high-severity issues.

tm-data-engineering: 72 high-severity vulnerabilities identified. Six critical (C) vulnerabilities are being addressed first.

data-api-express: 90 medium-severity vulnerabilities reviewed.

tm-ml-chat: 18 high-severity vulnerabilities investigated.

Progress & Next Steps:

Developers have been assigned to resolve dependency-related issues.

DevOps-related vulnerabilities are currently under review.

Some vulnerabilities require package upgrades that may introduce breaking changes; testing is needed before implementation.

Documentation of remediation steps is in progress.

data.title: Trading Agent V2 Design - Trading History
data.description:
Trading Agent V2 Design - Trading History

[Trading History - TMAI_task (Figma)](https://www.figma.com/design/74Zz1grTtdFlkydLSZe3q7/TMAI_task?node-id=9340-27781&t=wEmncHAyZT9swK3c-4)

Groomed Issue:

**Title:** Trading Agent V2 Design - Trading History

**Description:**
Redesign the Trading History feature for Trading Agent V2 to enhance user experience and functionality, following the latest design specifications outlined in Figma.

**Business Rationale:**
Improving the Trading History will provide users with a more intuitive and comprehensive view of their trading activities, leading to increased user satisfaction and engagement. Aligning this feature with the V2 redesign ensures consistency across the platform and supports future scalability.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. The Trading History interface matches the Figma design [link](https://www.figma.com/design/74Zz1grTtdFlkydLSZe3q7/TMAI_task?node-id=9340-27781&t=wEmncHAyZT9swK3c-4).
2. Users can view a complete list of their trading activities with relevant details.
3. Filtering and searching capabilities are implemented as specified in the design.
4. Integration with Privy/Fiat Gateways from V1 is maintained and functions correctly.
5. The feature is responsive and operates smoothly across all supported devices and browsers.
6. All functionalities pass QA testing with no critical issues.

**Parent Task:** \[PARENT\] Trading Agent V2 - Redesign Implementation

data.description:

[Portfolio Overview - TMAI_task (Figma)](https://www.figma.com/design/74Zz1grTtdFlkydLSZe3q7/TMAI_task?node-id=9340-19963&t=wEmncHAyZT9swK3c-4)

Groomed Issue:

**Title:** Trading Agent V2 - My Portfolio Page Redesign

**Description:**
Redesign and implement the "My Portfolio" page for the Trading Agent V2 feature according to the provided Figma design [Portfolio Overview - TMAI_task](https://www.figma.com/design/74Zz1grTtdFlkydLSZe3q7/TMAI_task?node-id=9340-19963&t=wEmncHAyZT9swK3c-4).

Enhancing the "My Portfolio" page will improve user engagement and satisfaction by providing a more intuitive and visually appealing interface. This redesign aims to offer clearer insights into users' investment performance and trading activities, thereby increasing the overall effectiveness of the Trading Agent feature.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. The "My Portfolio" page accurately reflects the layout and design specifications from the Figma prototype.
2. All interactive elements (e.g., charts, buttons, data tables) function correctly and responsively across supported devices and browsers.
3. Real-time portfolio data is integrated and displays accurately without significant latency.
4. The page adheres to accessibility standards, ensuring usability for all users.
5. Successful completion of user acceptance testing with no critical issues identified.

data.title: Front End Implementation of Trading Agent V2 Design - Launch Agent Modal
data.description:
Groomed Issue:

**Title:** Front End Implementation of Trading Agent V2 – Launch Agent Modal

**Description:**  
Develop the Launch Agent modal for the Trading Agent V2 interface, enabling users to initiate and configure new trading agents seamlessly. This modal should adhere to the latest design specifications and integrate smoothly with existing frontend components.

**Business Rationale:**  
Introducing the Launch Agent modal enhances user experience by providing a straightforward and efficient way to create and manage trading agents. This functionality is expected to increase user engagement and satisfaction, ultimately driving higher adoption rates of the Trading Agent V2 platform.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

* The Launch Agent modal matches the provided design specifications precisely.
* Accessible via the Trading Agent V2 interface with appropriate navigation.
* Includes all necessary input fields for configuring a trading agent (e.g., name, strategy parameters).
* Implements validation for all input fields, displaying clear error messages for invalid entries.
* Ensures responsiveness and compatibility across major browsers and devices.
* Successfully creates a trading agent upon valid submission and provides user feedback.
* Passes all frontend testing protocols and receives approval in code reviews.

data.description:
[https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1lPTYrsBRCXt60NFKF1yDqBT3Pc72FJKBPM-oVWR8AC0/edit?gid=1913179571#gid=1913179571](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1lPTYrsBRCXt60NFKF1yDqBT3Pc72FJKBPM-oVWR8AC0/edit?gid=1913179571#gid=1913179571)

Groomed Issue:

**Title:** Deploy to Production with Go/No-Go Checklist and Rollback Procedure

**Description:**
Develop a comprehensive go/no-go checklist to evaluate readiness before deploying Trading on Token Metrics to production. Additionally, document a clear rollback procedure to address and revert any severe issues that may arise post-launch.

**Business Rationale:**
Implementing a structured deployment process ensures that all critical factors are assessed, reducing the risk of deployment failures. A documented rollback procedure provides a safety mechanism to quickly mitigate issues, maintaining system integrity and minimizing downtime, thereby safeguarding business operations and user trust.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. A detailed go/no-go checklist is created, covering all necessary pre-deployment criteria.
2. A step-by-step rollback procedure is documented for handling severe post-launch issues.
3. Both documents are reviewed and approved by the relevant stakeholders.
4. The checklist and rollback procedure are easily accessible to the deployment and support teams.
5. Training or a briefing is conducted to ensure all involved parties understand the checklist and rollback steps.

data.title: Peer Review (Token Details Swaps) - Anki
data.description:
For major projects, **every developer** should participate in a comprehensive, end-to-end review. While GitHub peer reviews are valuable, they often focus on smaller code segments. This expanded process involves:

1. **Full-Project Audits**: Each developer examines the entire codebase, not just isolated PRs.
2. **Hands-On Testing**: Reviewers clone the repository, run the project in a **staging environment**, and actively **test functionality** to identify hidden issues.
3. **Cross-Team Involvement**: Team members outside the immediate project also join in, providing fresh perspectives and “tearing it apart” to find potential weaknesses.
4. **Knowledge Sharing**: As everyone reviews the code, they gain a deeper understanding of the project’s architecture and dependencies, strengthening overall team expertise.
5. **Mandatory Checkpoint**: Before release, ensure that each developer’s feedback has been addressed, documented, and signed off in **Linear** or the relevant project management tool.

Implementing this **full-project peer review** ensures higher code quality, reduces bugs in production, and encourages a culture of shared ownership and continuous learning.

comments.body:
## Overview: * **Imports and Dependencies**: * The component imports a variety of utilities and components, but some libariry quite of large like `solana/web3.js` and `ethers` * **State Management**: * The component uses useState to manage local state, including swap state, wallet balance, and UI states like loading indicators. * useMemo is used to derive values like `isTokenSupported`, `isSolanaFromChain`, and `userAddress` based on dependencies. * **Handlers and Effects**: * The `handleSwap` function is an async function that executes the swap and handles success and error states. * `fetchBalances` is a callback function to fetch wallet balances. * `useEffect` hooks are used to fetch balances and initialize tokens when dependencies change. ## **Potential Improvements:** * Consider breaking down the component into smaller sub-components or custom hooks to improve readability and maintainability. * Move this logic to a constant or utility for reusability and to avoid magic variables. ```typescriptreact chainId = "1151111081099710"; tokenAddress = tokenAddress === "0x0000000000000000000000000000000000000000" ? "11111111111111111111111111111111" : tokenAddress; ``` * Use React Query for improved readability, scalability, API call deduplication, and abort strategy implementation, also remove `useEffect` * getTokenData * getTokenBalanceFunc * Missing translation ```typescriptreact

For cross-chain swaps, where the tokens you are swapping are on different blockchains, you need to provide a wallet address on the destination blockchain to receive the purchased token.

``` Overall, the `SwapWidget` component is well-structured and functional, but breaking it down into smaller parts and enhancing type safety and error handling could further improve its quality cc @bartosz @suleman
@suleman confirm Anki has time to take this tomorrow. If not someone else should.

data.title: Astrobot Issue Unable to Login
data.description:
A. Resolve Coinbase Wallet Login Failure in Astrobot

**Description:**
Users are unable to log in to Astrobot using their Coinbase Wallet, specifically with the address 0x80091e29fFa0e2bf27Ef37C7C8ca9F7Ba1366f1A. Attempts result in authentication errors as indicated by console logs and network requests. [View detailed logs](https://jam.dev/c/cb04266a-9bc1-412a-b657-d0fce44de17f).

**Business Rationale:**
Facilitating seamless login with popular wallets like Coinbase is essential for user satisfaction and retention. Addressing this issue will enhance user accessibility, trust, and overall platform engagement.

**Acceptance Criteria:**

1. Users can successfully log in to Astrobot using their Coinbase Wallet without errors.
2. The authentication process completes smoothly, verified by successful console logs and network requests.
3. The issue is tested and confirmed across multiple Coinbase Wallet addresses.
4. Relevant automated tests are updated or created to ensure ongoing functionality.

B.  0x8E9825261dF78C27730bab30c92A5Cc64D29f7B8 - Astrobot - PREMIUM  PLAN 

> User is able to login but he gets this tag - "connection success and then conection failed."
> 
> LINK - [https://we.tl/t-G2T1rVipDb](https://we.tl/t-G2T1rVipDb)

3. 0x005E9f8E7dE28bfAf94b74d33fD7fEfe5541f08d - ADVANCED Astrobot - PREMIUM PLAN
4. 0x2Ec859CDa876b8708E8db5A636772748A8724A2f - PREMIUM Astrobot - PREMIUM PLAN

comments.body: It seems to fix the MetaMask login issue for me.

@ian this update is already on production as part of the fix for general nft login issue we were having today. We switched to using privy on signin instead of wagmi as well in this update.

@bartosz this specific issue seems to be pointing towards coinbase wallet login rather than metamask, can you test that as well and post a jam dev for it, thanks.

@bartosz rhanks for resolving. What was the issue?

@suleman let's deploy this to production once @val confirms it works for the customer.
[https://jam.dev/c/ea0e1dba-7b9a-4bf8-a4b7-cc4013727ed7](https://jam.dev/c/ea0e1dba-7b9a-4bf8-a4b7-cc4013727ed7)

data.title: Testing & QA and Prepare to Production of On-chain swaps (Collaborate with Marketing)
data.description:
* **Task: Conduct functional, integration, and usability testing on staging.**
  * For **Web3 features**, involve the **Research Team** in testing to validate on-chain interactions and compatibility.
  * Testing Starts with QA (Ozcan), then moves to Product team. 
  * Lastly before Unguess we have a Test Party. 
* **Deliverable: Prepare to launch with feature flags. Signed-off release plan with rollback instructions. For the Canary Rollout** we will start at 10% traffic for 24 hours with monitoring. If stable, scale to 50%, then 100% after verifying metrics.
* **Task: Fix bugs and ensure the MVP meets acceptance criteria.**
* **Deliverable: QA-approved MVP, ready for production deployment.**
* **Deliverable: Production-ready product with Automation testing.**
* Deliverable: Collaborate with Product team to get the feature to Unguess for Testing.
